Yes, there have been instances where political murals have caused tension between the government and the artists. Governments or authorities may view some political murals as vandalism, as they can be seen as damaging to public property or as a violation of public space.

For example, in the United States in the 1980s, the Reagan administration passed a series of laws that made it illegal for artists to paint on walls or public spaces. This was in response to the increasing prevalence of graffiti and street art, which were often seen as a form of vandalism.

In other cases, the government or authorities may view political murals as a threat to national security or as a means of subversion. For example, in Iran, political murals that criticize the government or that depict women in a non-traditional way are often censored or painted over.

There have also been instances where artists have faced legal action or censorship for their political murals. In some cases, the artists themselves may become targets of harassment or violence from government or non-state actors who disagree with their message.

Overall, political murals can be a powerful means of expression, but they can also be controversial and cause tension between the artists and the government or other elements of society.
